Definition: Given a prompt and four completions, select the completion that is the most plausible in continuing or answering the prompt. The task is designed to test common sense and has various categories ranging between idioms, negated statements, polysemy, subject referencing, and quantitative reasoning. Generate either Completion A, Completion B, Completion C, or Completion D.

Positive Examples.input:
Prompt: A clown is fashioning animals from long balloons. He 
Completion A: releases the animals into their natural habitat. 
Completion B: makes a giraffe and hands it to a child. 
Completion C: yells out for his second in command to pilot the battleship around the obstacle. 
Completion D: releases the balloon and it flies high into the air.
Positive Examples.explanation: The clown is an entertainer and is twisting balloons to resemble an animal. There are no live animals, and these types of twistable balloons are not able to fly or float up.

Positive Examples.input:
Prompt: I am feeling hungry. I think I will 
Completion A: call my mother. 
Completion B: have some ravioli. 
Completion C: fly out the window. 
Completion D: go on a run outside.
Positive Examples.explanation: If one is hungry, then they will eat some food to satiate their hunger. One must look at the entire context rather than just the current sentence when selecting the best completion to the prompt.

Positive Examples.input:
Prompt: I am feeling nervous about my midterm tomorrow. I fear that 
Completion A: the professor will delay the midterm. 
Completion B: I will doodle on my exam and receive points for it. 
Competion C: my grandpa has diabetes. 
Completion D: I will fail.
Positive Examples.explanation: If one is feeling nervous about their midterm the next day, then they are most likely worried and anxious about the grade they will receive. They will not doodle on their exam because they will surely not do well in that case. The professor delaying a midterm is usually not why a person would feel nervous about the midterm. One may be worried about their grandpa having diabetes, but that is not relevant to taking a midterm.

Negative Examples.input:
Prompt: The man entered his house. The man 
Completion A: can't find the keys to unlock the door. 
Completion B: goes to school at his university. 
Completion C: eats the garbage. 
Completion D: takes his shoes off.
Negative Examples.explanation: The man must have found the keys to unlock the door in order to have entered his house in the first place. After he entered the house, it is most plausible that he took his shoes off to not get his house dirty. Thus, Completion D is actually the correct answer.

Negative Examples.input:
The boy likes animals, but only invertebrates. He 
Completion A: likes pigs. 
Completion B: likes vertebrates. 
Completion C: likes spiders. 
Completion D: likes elephants.
Negative Examples.explanation: Out of the four possible completions, only one of them mentions an invertebrate. Spiders are invertebrates since they do not have a spine or vertebral column. Thus, Completion C is actually the correct answer.

Instances.input:
Prompt: The politician really wanted to win their campaign for governor. The politician 
Completion A: took bribes and attacked people physically. 
Completion B: talked frankly and honestly about their love of financial meltdowns. 
Completion C: took counsel from professional advisers.  
Completion D: committed them self to helping other people steal from taxpayers.

Prompt: I like to take a walk after supper, but it's raining outside. So I decide to 
Completion A: wash my hands. 
Completion B: stay at home. 
Completion C: go out for a walk. 
Completion D: lock the door.

Prompt: A woman is riding her bike. She 
Completion A: transforms into a robot. 
Completion B: finds an apple inside a mailbox. 
Completion C: shifts to another gear when approaching the hill. 
Completion D: levitates down the street on her bike.

Prompt: The man wanted fried chicken for dinner but his wife did not. He 
Completion A: chased the chicken 
Completion B: bought chicken and fries 
Completion C: dined the chicken 
Completion D: convinced her otherwise

Prompt: Because I never turned in my TB confirmation test, my school 
Completion A: failed me in all my classes. 
Completion B: forced me to play for the school football team 
Completion C: put a hold on my account. 
Completion D: gave me a free burrito

Prompt: John is currently swimming with goggles that don't leak. His eyes 
Completion A: are open and viewing the pool. 
Completion B: are small. 
Completion C: sting with water. 
Completion D: are crying.

Prompt: After being bullied by classmates, Thomas 
Completion A: shaved his head. 
Completion B: wrote a love letter to his teacher. 
Completion C: was afraid of going to school. 
Completion D: became the top detective in Chicago.

Prompt: A photographer sets up his tripod. He 
Completion A: is asked for pictures of Spider-Man, tells The Daily Bugle no, and throws his tripod. 
Completion B: adjusts the aperture and exposure, balances the color, and then realizes that he himself is not a tripod. 
Completion C: looks out for the next best shot. 
Completion D: places his camera on top, surveys the landscape, and then angrily kicks over his tripod.
